releasenotes/notes/victoria-m2-release-n.message:
unowned

Though that makes it sound like these images don't have any owners, but it's actually that someone can copy the image even though it is owned by someone else, right? Maybe something like:

Added policy support to allow copying image to multiple stores, even if those images are not owned by the current user's project.
We don't want a second level of bulleting. Each item in the release note is generated as a bullet item list, so this adds a second level.
Looks like we already have a release note for this. Though the existing one has some formatting issues.

api-ref/source/v2/images-import.inc.message:
Since api users can't change policy, you should probably just say

- By default, you may perform the copy-image operation only on images that you own.  This action is governed by policy, so some users may be granted permission to copy unowned images.  Consult your cloud's local documentation for details.
I have changed the wording as suggested by Brian.

FWIW, I don't think it's problematic to mention policy in here specifically, as operators may read this as well trying to perform things themselves, especially things like copy-image that are admin-focused most of the time.

However, I just scanned the rest of the file here and see no other mention of policy. I'm not sure if that's because most of your policy is pretty rigidly enforced at lower layers than the API or what.

FWIW, the nova api-ref guideline doc specifically asks for mentioning policy elements that can be tweaked (policy under this paragraph):

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/api-ref-guideline.html#description

and we do, here's an example:

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#server-usage-audit-log-os-instance-usage-audit-log

Maybe just a wording change would help make it more clear (as in the nova example above) that the statement is focused on the operator?

doc/source/admin/interoperable-image-imp.message:
The default is role:admin. I think you want to either just say something generic here like "To allow copy-image operation to be performed by users on images they do not own, you can set the copy_image policy to something other than the default."

If you want an example, I think using the is_public one I have for the nova job would be most likely to be useful:

 "'public':%(visibility)s"
I don't think this is true by default, is it? Or do you mean "the most you can grant is copy permission to images the user can see?"
This is a good point to make.

.zuul.yaml.message: Remove setup.cfg from this list.  (See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/521654/ )
best practice would be to just name this nodeset after fedora version
(and jobs as well for that matter)

IIUC the idea was that we could just update the nodeset and wouldn't have to update everything in all branches in order to make the switch. Fedora is special in that regard because it doesn't have LTS, so we need to cycle through the releases much faster than for other distros in order to avoid running EOL stuff.

But maybe you are right and we should follow the same naming scheme here and just drop EOL things then in stable branches.

docker/services/derive_pci_passthrough_w.message: Why is this using Jinja's raw block (or any Jinja)? Using the 'copy' module to copy it will not render out any Jinja templates (that is what the 'template' module is for). Does the destination file eventually get treated as a Jinja template elsewhere?
I think it's because of the get_file which is a heat action to include this file in the template output.

ideally ansible's copy module shall not use template, but here we are using "get_file" which is a heat function.
Since the get_file content is wrongly processed and throws up template errors, raw has been added these errors

openstack_releases/cmds/list_unreleased_.message:
I don't think we want to do this. This adds unnecessary delay, not to mention the potential for data corruption if one of our variables ends up being wrong.

The cloning operation will check if the repo is already present here:

https://opendev.org/openstack/releases/src/commit/62c2fc43176363f8738effef20b72468d5190e34/tools/clone_repo.sh#L158

That's fine. Then it just knows that it does not need to attempt to do a full clone again.

Then later on, it will make sure to fetch the latest:

https://opendev.org/openstack/releases/src/commit/62c2fc43176363f8738effef20b72468d5190e34/tools/clone_repo.sh#L175-L177

And then whether it had freshly cloned earlier or not, it goes into the local clone and checks out the requested branch:

https://opendev.org/openstack/releases/src/commit/62c2fc43176363f8738effef20b72468d5190e34/tools/clone_repo.sh#L187

So we should not need to start from scratch.

specs/victoria/port-numa-affinity-policy.message:
or macvtap and i think virtio-forwarder.

if you use sriov in any form we apply the legacy policy unless you override that in the flavor or image. users dont currently have a way to express a requirement outside of the falvor or image they choose.

this is not correct 

the numa aware vswitch spec
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/rocky/implemented/numa-aware-vswitches.html

added static config driven appoch which is not visabel to end users and there is no way for end users to express policy over it.

if its configured you get numa affinity between numa instance and the netwrok physnet or tunnel provider.

so the behavior is to apply the legacy policy.

if numa info is avaiable we use it and enforece affintiy if
no numa info is in the config we ignore the netwrok numa affintiy. that is the default policy for sriov too.
I should have rephrased that paragraph before. I should not talk about NUMA nodes but NUMA policies. Thanks

from a nova point of view hardware offloaded ovs is just sriov and the exsting sriov numa affinity extra specs and polices are enforced. this includes netronomes virtio-forwarded hardware offloaded ovs as well as meloxes approch which uses vnic type driect
Correct, I'll remove this use case because it's already covered with the current functionality.

So why should neutron port be involved at all? Nova has physnet info (either from port provided or from server request), physnet-NUMA mapping and affinity policy could be taken from flavor I believe. I might be missing something.
Ah, I didn't account for the case with multiple ports, thanks
I'll add this info to the spec.

And you are right, the phynet can have a set of NUMA nodes defined statically in the Nova config and the flavor can define a PCI NUMA affinity policy.

But this spec superseeds this parameter and includes all type of ports, not only the PCI ones (SR-IOV).

That will be very useful for DPDK OVS ports (with PMD threads pinned to certain cores and NUMA nodes) or HW offload OVS, where the NIC is located in a specific NUMA node PCI bus.

Of course, this is an extension and the default policy for a port, if enabled, will be "None".

Extending to all types of ports makes sense, but why can't this be done in flavor: PCI NUMA affinity policy -> NUMA affinity policy? So neutron provides port with type and physnet (as usual), and nova decides which NUMA to place the VM based on these and on flavor's NUMA policy. My concern is that having additional source of NUMA affinity policy complicates things.

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/ussuri/implemented/vm-scoped-sriov-numa-affinity.html#alternatives

this was always intended to be a follow on to the flavor appoch.

the flaovr based approch only works if you want the same policy for all prots.

so if we had a new hw:port_numa_affinity extra spec that applied to all port and you set it to strict.
that would mean that if you have a vm with an ovs managment port and an sriov data plane port, the vm could only be schduled on a host with sirov port that report numa affinity and has numa aware vstich configured.

that could result in a no valid host on a public cloud where you have no viablity into if they configured numa aware vswtichs or not.

if you jsut use the existing extra spec and set strict for the sriov ports and they do have numa aware vswtch configured it might still fail if it can meet the sriov requirement but not the vswitch affinity. if the vswitch port is jsut used for manament and you dont care about affiniy there is no way to express that today.


a per port policy allows you to actully say what your requirement are and if you dont use this feature it will have no effect  on behavior.

there are other networking relaated features that are confriugred by image porpeites like multi queue and vif_model that similarly should proably be 
specifed per port instead in a similar way but that is out of scope for now, i could see this  extention growing to include those aspecs if customer express interest in that.

we have had 1 custome ask for per port ability to enabel virtio multiqueue alsthough there usecase was not partaclly compelling.

for me expressing qualitiave aspecs of neutron ports via the neuton service and not nova flaour or glance images makes a lot of sense in the long run.

at first glance legacy woudl seem like a good default but since we want the new port peramater to take precedece over the falvor and image property we dont want to use legacy as the default.

the default as should be  None or unset as is being proposed so that the precedence can be applied only when the user configures the feature.

if we used legacy as the default here we would have to invert the precedence and give the image and flavor prcednece over the port to not change behavior on the nova side which is not what we want.

I need to clarify this in this spec. The Neutron stored value can be (None, required, preferred, legacy).

If "None" is stored, no "required" parameter (trait) will be passed in the "request_resources" dict. That will be backwards compatible.

If any other option is selected, the corresponding trait will be passed in the "required" list.

am since this will be a new extention
can we conditionally block update of this attibute while the port is attached to an instnace.

nova should not  act on the new affinity if it was modifed while attached so it would be nice to block that at the api level if we can.

updating it is fine but only when its not attached.

on a related not nova does not today support attaching inteface with resouce requests to a vm.

glance/async_/__init__.py.message: I'm not exactly sure what the current preference for this is but thus far we have avoided asserts in logic for those who run the service under PyPy with -OO. Do we actually break something if this assert on line 173 is just skipped?

No, it's mostly just to help developers realize they've done something wrong and to avoid something (like tests) trying to switch the model at runtime without being explicit about it.

This should never happen in production, so running with assertions disabled is fine. If you want to raise something different here we can, but optimizing out the assertion for non-debugging cases is actually what you want.

As sean-k-mooney noted [1], there was a change in the past to bump the default to 100G and that was backported to nautilus BUT we are pulling tag 14.2.2 which does not contain the backport.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2020-07-24.log.html#t2020-07-24T17:43:57

I was referring to the change from xfs to blue that came with nautilus. However, we're doing this on a loop mount of 24G, on a filesystem of no more than 80G. Assuming it's not creating a sparse file, we probably need to set this ourselves, even if it's smaller vs. larger in the future :)

devstacks defaul will make CEPH_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE 24G
and the plugins default would make it 8G even if you used it without devstack so ya i think we can just assume that if you set those to 4 or less that ceph will be unhappy.

i dont really think its worth overcomplicating this since the pluging is just for testing anyway.

no one is running devstack with ceph in production outside of ci.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: the other hosts dont have multi numa or have hyperthread siblings so you will need to make those test dynamic since the cpu topology is different.

FN (well, OpenEdge now) is down and will remain that way for a significant amount of time (see NODE_FAILURE on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/737005/ and https://review.opendev.org/#/c/736820/). We have no choice but to switch, so yeah, I'll have to add a patch underneath this that makes SMT hosts configurable.

if your going to disabel this via config you need to write a pre palyboox that will generate a local.sh to set the new config vaule dynamically.

the flavor provided by fort nebula was spcificaly created to have numa nodes and smt so we could test with smt.

so this change is functially a regression in testing upstream as it stands so we should try not to reguress by simply testing if the hosts support smt and populated the confg value dynmaically.

Fort Nebula is being very iffy (currently down because it needs a new AC) and we can't really rely on it. I agree with everything that you've said, but currently the gate is blocked, and we need to unblock it. We could eventually have a second non-voting Fort Nebula job with SMT and multi NUMA, but I don't think we should block on FN for landing code.

non of the test here are acutlly using multiple numa nodes why is why i dont think this is correct.

they are specificaly testing cpu pinning in different forms
this should work if the host does not have hypertreading

the prefer policy does not guarentted that.

it is ment to prefer host that have hypertreads but if the host does not have hyperthread then its still valid for the vm to spawn. this test is not written correctly.

unless we start doing testing with multiple numa does i still think this rename is incorrect as you are explcitly testing cpu pinning in this module and are not usein
the hw:numa_* extras specs.

we shoudl reserve teh test_numa module for that.

as noted on the previous patch this test is wrong and it should not have the skip decorator.

the prefer policy does not require hyperthreading.
we intended to have a weigher bias schduild to host that had hypertreading but not force it.

that is why the scheduler passes teh host so we should either delete this test or make it correct.

ansible/roles/monasca/templates/monasca-.message:
Thanks Nikolaos - they way I was thinking this should work is that we have monasca-persister on every node that hosts InfluxDB. So at the moment, the IP set here should be the IP of the InfluxDB instance on the same node. Then the Monasca API talks to InfluxDB via HAProxy, eg it has this in all instances of the Monasca API config file:

```
[influxdb]
database_name = monasca
ip_address = 192.0.2.10
port = 8086
```

Then HAProxy load balances over the replicas, eg:

```
bind 192.0.2.10:8086
    server secondary1 192.0.2.2:8086 check inter 2000 rise 2 fall 5 
    server secondary2 192.0.2.3:8086 check inter 2000 rise 2 fall 5 
    server primary 192.0.2.1:8086 check inter 2000 rise 2 fall 5 
```

Does that make sense, or did I miss something?

tempest/api/image/v2/test_images.py.message: I think you should s/_inject_metadata// and make this just an import test for the reason below. Also, don't you need to probe the API to see if glance is deployed with import enabled? If not, this test should skip I think.

Import workflow is enabled by default. We have removed config option which used to check if import workflow is enabled or not.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/572534/

This:

 https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/image/v2/index.html?expanded=import-methods-and-values-discovery-detail#import-methods-and-values-discovery

Glance should be able to not expose any methods if it's running in wsgi mode. Does it not do that?

We can also make devstack set enabled_import_methods="" if that's the way, but it seems like if glance knows that these will never work with wsgi mode, it should refuse to expose them if/when it's deployed like that.

If glance is in uwsgi mode then import will not work. This test can't fail in that case, because tempest has no control over how the deployment was configured. That's why this is failing on all the stable jobs.

Doesn't glance expose a capability via the API that the client uses to determine if import is possible?

Since this is config-based, I think you probably should not depend on this from a tempest test. If someone runs this against their own deployment without the same config that I added in that job, it will fail.
can we verify it via API? or updating images or adding tags should be ok to verify if image is imported fine ?

This was left over from a previous discussion I had with Abhi where I explained we can't really depend on the job's metadata injection here. We were going to remove it, we just haven't yet.

But, as we just discussed on IRC, if the image goes from queued->active then we know the import worked.

we can just pass to API what test want to pass and return what API return. and test side we can control if they are passing all_stores_must_succeed based on glance backends configuration.

let's return body here as copy-image tests need what all stores are enabled to verify if image is copied or not

deployment/nova/novajoin-container-puppe.message:
Incorrect file path on host
/etc/novajoin/join-api-paste.ini I guess
what is generated these files on the hosts?

They are installed by the novajoin rpm package

btw, here are the logs with the error
https://review.rdoproject.org/zuul/build/3f8b74e0a0014504929ae8ca5f2b871d/log/logs/undercloud/var/log/extra/podman/containers/novajoin_server/stdout.log.txt.gz
these files aren't needed for novajoin_notifier as well?
It does not look like it requires anything from api-paste.ini. May be transport_url or firewall?

you might be right, it looks like there is some issue with the notifier as well https://review.rdoproject.org/zuul/build/3f8b74e0a0014504929ae8ca5f2b871d/log/logs/undercloud/var/log/extra/podman/containers/novajoin_notifier/stdout.log.txt.gz

Why are we being selective? In all the other ones we merge the puppet generated files in to the container on launch. 

          config_files:
            - source: "/var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/*"
              dest: "/"
              merge: true
              preserve_properties: true

you need:

            - source: "/var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/*"
              dest: "/"
              merge: true
              preserve_properties: true

OK, then perhaps we should use /var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/novajoin/* instead of just this specific file.  My concern is that we end up not getting other files that we might need. Are we sure this is the only file?

That's what caused a failure in the previous run [1]. We only need the join.conf, but the directory contains other files, like krb5.conf, which is what generated the error.

[1] https://review.rdoproject.org/zuul/build/3ab9e4ddc6484863a7b5a8a8f03c93af/log/logs/undercloud/var/log/containers/novajoin/novajoin-server.log.txt.gz

The krb5.conf and other files that might cause issues are in the /etc/novajoin directory, so this wouldn't work.

I'm sure that's the correct solution, since, that's the one file that we made the initial change for, we didn't mount or copy over other files.

playbooks/roles/bifrost-deploy-nodes-dyn.message: this should not need bool conversion as noauth_mode is true or false
We've hit the issues with it before though. Here is an example: when I run ansible-playbook with `-e auth_mode=true`, is true automatically converted to a boolean?

ok, I think for the sake of the sanity of the final users I'm convinced we should keep the |bool filter
change to json is utopia at the moment :)
Correct. And we use the former syntax in a few places (and can safely expect users to try the same).

that's because of an "interesting" ansible behavior:
- if you pass extra-vars using the key=value syntax, they're interpreted as strings, e.g. --extra-vars "version=1.2.3 foo=false" -> 1.2.3 and false are strings
- if you want to pass a pure boolean (or some other non-string format, like integer, float, lists, etc.), you need to use the json syntax, e.g. --extra-vars "{'foo': true, 'bar': 1}" -> true is boolean, 1 is integer

ditto
if a variable is set as false or true, doesn't need bool conversion

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message:
Some questions/comments:

1) IMO, this is not an error if this is going to be part of a normal deployment use case. If we need to support those tags, we can't log an error here.

2) If we don't raise an exception and continue the processing, when we create/update the port, we get the DHCP options in [1]. If an option is not valid, we are already logging a warning message. IMO, that's enough.

Conclusion: that should be just an INFO message. I don't know if you agree with me.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/9717fea647b3836ba305450bb10989d0d25af7ed/neutron/common/ovn/utils.py#L154

Hi Rodolfo, 

You have a great point, indeed I think ERROR might be misleading here cause the code actually won't "error out" or anything.

I do agree with you, I will change the log level to INFO as you suggested.

Thanks for that.

cinder/image/image_utils.py.message: I wonder if we should move this out of the "if".  execute() can raise ProcessExecutionError or OSError.  If it's OSError, we're probably hosed, so maybe just let that go, but since we're not setting check_exit_code in the call to execute(), any non-zero result from the qemu-convert will raise a ProcessExecutionError, in which case there's no reason to keep around the dest, so might as well delete it if it exists before we raise.

Since the original issue was reported when there was no space left on the disk, i added it in the if block.
but as we want to clean that image anyway, it makes sense outside the if block as well.

I suggest adding a note in this docstring saying something like:

NOTE: if the qemu-img convert command fails and this function raises an exception, a non-empty dest file may be left in the filesystem.  It is the responsibility of the caller to decide what to do with this file.

cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py.message: What's your theory about what's happening here?  As Fernando points out, the context manager should delete the file if an exception occurs within the context.  I suspect because we're passing the file out to the operating system to be executed, there's another file handle being held (ours in python plus the one "out there") that's preventing deletion.  If that's the case, I wonder whether the below statements are really cleaning stuff up.  oslo fileutils uses os.unlink() whose docs say "On Windows, attempting to remove a file that is in use causes an exception to be raised; on Unix, the directory entry is removed but the storage allocated to the file is not made available until the original file is no longer in use."  So I wonder whether the temporary storage is being deleted, or just the directory entry, in which case we're just treating a symptom.

Hi Rajat, I may be wrong but _TemporaryFileWrapper [1] should guarantee the temp file deletion in a with statement.

[1] https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/5d1f32d33ba24d0aa87235ae40207bb57778388b/Lib/tempfile.py#L490

Looks like the NamedTemporaryFile is handed to you in a wrapper that defines __enter__() and __exit__() methods, so it does implement the context manager interface, just not using the decorators.

My point about os.unlink is that if the reason why the cleanup isn't happening in the normal (context manager) case is that some other process is holding an open file handle, then calling os.unlink via fileutils may be removing the directory entry but not actually freeing the storage (at least the docs say that's what can happen).  In other words, the file no longer showing as existing in a directory may not actually mean that the resource we're worried about has been freed up.

How often does this happen?  If it happens a lot, then we do want to make sure we're fixing the right thing.
Good point. As much as it's interesting to find out why that doesn't happen. This patch is still a safety mechanism to ensure we delete it if it's leftout which is currently the issue.

It should've if the NamedTemporaryFile method was defined properly to be used as a context[1].
It doesn't use the contextmanager decorator, and should ideally have this try, finally block to handle the cleanup but it doesn't which makes me wonder why we use that method like this here anyway.
Regarding the os.unlink point, the exception occurred so we can safely assume the file isn't in use and will be deleted.
the same fileutils module is used in rest of cinder to perform the cleanup.
Also Sofia tested this out with the exception and the results are expected.

[1] https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Lib/tempfile.py#L514

Nice work tracking this down.  I wonder whether it might be better to handle this within the convert_image function so that the caller doesn't have to worry about it, though.  Either way, I'd suggest adding a docstring to image_utils.convert_image() saying something about it cleaning up after itself.
Yeah, i checked all the calls and no caller is taking care of the residue file so i also think it's better to be handled in convert_image.
